questions.text: Which of the following is the cause of the closure of ductus arteriosus?
questions.explanation:
Parameter/Structure

Change

Cause

Pulmonary Vascular Resistance (PVR)

Decreases

(Option C)

Mechanical expansion of the lungs and increased arterial PO2 lead to a rapid decrease in PVR.

Systemic Vascular Resistance (SVR)

Increases

The removal of the low-resistance placental circulation results in an increase in SVR.

Ductus Arteriosus Shunt

Reverses and eventually closes.

As PVR becomes lower than SVR, the shunt through the ductus arteriosus reverses from right-to-left to left-to-right.

High arterial PO2 leads to the constriction and eventual closure of the ductus arteriosus, which later becomes the ligamentum arteriosum.

Foramen Ovale

Closes

Increased pulmonary blood flow to the left atrium raises left atrial volume and pressure, leading to the functional closure of the foramen ovale.

Ductus Venosus

Closes

The removal of the placenta from circulation results in the closure of the ductus venosus.

Left ventricular Wall Thickness and Mass

Increases

The left ventricle's wall thickness and mass increase as it adapts to the high-resistance systemic circulation.

Right ventricular Wall Thickness and Mass

Decreases


 

The right ventricle's wall thickness and mass decrease as it adapts to the low-resistance pulmonary circulation.

Left Ventricular Output

Increases

The left ventricle now must deliver the entire systemic cardiac output, which is almost a 200% increase compared to fetal conditions.

Right Ventricular Output

Increases

Opening of pulmonary vasculature results in increased right ventricular output.

Shunt

Functional Closure

Anatomical closure

Remnant

Ductus Arteriosus

10-15 hrs after birth

2 -3 weeks after birth

Ligamentum arteriosum

Foramen ovale

3rd month

1 year after birth

Fossa ovalis

Ductus venosus

Immediately after birth

3-7 days after birth

Ligamentum venosum.

questions.text: In newborns, what is the primary cause of ventriculomegaly?
questions.explanation: Correct Option D: Aquedu

questions.text: Continuous murmur is heard in?
questions.explanation: Correct Option A - Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA)

questions.text: Which of the following is not a characteristic of tetralogy of Fallot?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer C- A

questions.text: Which of the following congenital heart disease presents with split-second heart sounds? Atrial Septal Defect (ASD) Ventricular Septal Defect (VSD) Patent Ductus Arteriosus (PDA) Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF)
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer A- Only 1,2,3 is correct

Examination findings in TOF

Cardiac Auscultation
  • Heart Sounds: Typically normal first heart sound with a single second heart sound (pulmonic component usually inaudible)
  • Murmur: Harsh systolic ejection murmur, crescendo-decrescendo in quality
    • Best heard at the left mid to upper sternal border
    • Radiates posteriorly
    • The severity of the murmur correlates with the degree of right ventricular outflow tract obstruction
    • May occasionally have a regurgitant quality
  • Early systolic click: Sometimes heard along the left sternal border (attributed to flow through a dilated ascending aorta)
  • Continuous murmur: Present over the back and axillary regions in patients with pulmonary atresia and aortopulmonary collaterals

Palpation
  • Prominent ventricular impulse
  • Systolic thrill may be palpable along the left sternal border

 

Wide Splitting
  • Occurs in conditions like right bundle branch block (RBBB) due to delayed pulmonic valve closure.
  • Seen in severe mitral regurgitation (MR) due to premature closure of the aortic valve- Wide and variable split is seen.
  • Seen in VSD

Narrow Splitting or Singular S2
  • Narrow Splitting- E.g. Aortic stenosis or Patent Ductus Arteriosus

Wide Fixed Splitting
  • The A2-P2 interval is wide and does not change during the respiratory cycle. E.g.- ASD, TAPVC, RVF

Reversed or Paradoxical Splitting- P2 before A2
  • Seen in conditions such as left bundle branch block (LBBB).
  • Right ventricular pacing.
  • Severe aortic stenosis (AS).
  • Hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy (HOCM),
  • Acute myocardial ischemia.

Loud P2
  • Considered loud when its intensity exceeds A2 at the base or can be palpated in the proximal main pulmonary artery area. E.g.- Pulmonary arterial hypertension.

Decreased Intensity
  • A2 intensity decreases with aortic stenosis (AS) and P2 intensity decreases with pulmonic stenosis (PS), potentially resulting in a single S2.

questions.text: The given chest x-ray is suggestive of :
questions.explanation:
Snowman or "figure-of-eight" appearance: seen in Total anomalous pulmonary venous connection (TAPVC)"

Scimitar sign: seen in Partial Anomalous Pulmonary Venous Connection (PAPVC)
 

Box-shaped heart: seen in Ebstein’s anomaly

Gooseneck deformity: seen in

endocardial cushion defects

questions.text: Which of the following features can be alleviated by performing surgical correction of VSD in an infant?
Which of the following vessels is responsible for returning deoxygenated blood back to the placenta in fetal circulation?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer B - Umbilical artery

Structure

Number

Type of Blood

Flow of blood

Umbilical Artery

2

Deoxygenated blood

Fetus to the placenta

Umbilical Vein

1

Oxygenated blood

Placenta to the fetus

questions.text: Which congenital heart disease exhibits equivalent saturation levels across all heart chambers?
questions.correct_answer: B. Total anomalous pulmonary venous circulation
questions.explanation: Correct Answer B - Total anomalous pulmonary venous circu

questions.text: A 6-year-old child was brought to her paediatrician for routine well-child care. Her physical examination is normal except for a systolic murmur and a widely split-second heart sound that does not vary with respiration. She has no family history of heart disease. Which among the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer C - Atrial septal defect

Feature

Description

Left-to-Right Shunting

Oxygenated blood flows from the left to right atrium; the degree of shunting varies with defect size and vascular resistance.

Right Heart Volume Overload

Increased blood flow causes enlargement of the right atrium and ventricle, and dilation of the pulmonary artery.

Pulmonary Vascular Resistance

May increase with time, after remaining low during childhood, and lead to reversal of shunt and cyanosis.

Symptoms

Description

Asymptomatic

Many children are asymptomatic.

Failure to Thrive

Poor growth and weight gain.

Exercise Intolerance

Difficulty with physical activity.

Finding

Description

Widely Split and Fixed S2

The second heart sound is split and fixed due to increased right ventricular diastolic volume.

Systolic Ejection Murmur

Soft murmur at the left upper sternal border, caused by increased flow across the right ventricular outflow tract.

Mid-Diastolic Murmur

Rumbling murmur at the lower left sternal border due to increased flow across the tricuspid valve.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common association with Tetralogy of Fallot?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer C - Down’

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman presents for an antenatal check-up and is currently on lithium for her bipolar disorder. This drug must be stopped, due to the risk of development of which of the following conditions in the fetus?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer A - E

questions.text: An unconscious child is brought to the casualty. What is the correct sequence of the management? Assess breathing Assess pulse Assess response Start compressions Bag and mask ventilation

Which of the following cyanotic heart diseases causes increased pulmonary blood flow? Ebstein anomaly Tetralogy of Fallot Transposition of the great arteries (TGA) Total anomalous pulmonary venous communication (TAPVC)
questions.explanation:
Decreased Pulmonary Blood Flow

(Normal Pulmonary Artery Pressure)

Increased Pulmonary Blood Flow

(with Pulmonary Artery Hypertension)

Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF) (2)

Persistent Truncus Arteriosus

Double Outlet Right Ventricle (DORV) with VSD and Pulmonary Stenosis (PS)

Double Outlet Right Ventricle (DORV) with VSD

Tricuspid Atresia with VSD and PS

Tricuspid Atresia with Large VSD

Atrioventricular Septal Defect (AVSD) with PS

Non-Obstructive Total Anomalous Pulmonary Venous Connection (TAPVC) (4)

Transposition of the Great Arteries (TGA) with Congenitally Corrected Transposition (CCT) and PS

Transposition of the Great Arteries (TGA) (3): Simple or with Large VSD/PDA

Single Ventricle with PS

Single Ventricle

Other Univentricular Hearts with PS

Other Univentricular Hearts with PAH

Ebstein's Anomaly (1)

questions.text: Nada's Minor Criteria include Systolic murmur Grade 3 Diastolic murmur Abnormal second heart sound Abnormal BP
questions.explanation:
Major Criteria

Minor Criteria

Systolic murmur of Grade 3 or more

Systolic murmur less than Grade 3

Any diastolic murmur

Abnormal second heart sound (S2)

Cyanosis

Abnormal ECG

Congestive cardiac failure

Abnormal chest X-ray findings

Abnormal blood pressure (BP)

questions.text: What could be the possible diagnosis for a newborn exhibiting weak lower limb pulses and strong upper limb pulses?
questions.explanation:
Coarctation of the Aorta

Definition
  • Constrictions of the aorta of varying degrees at any point from the transverse arch to the iliac bifurcation.

Clinical presentation:
  • Differential cyanosis
  • Heart failure in severe cases
  • Weakness or pain/claudication (or both) in the legs after exercise
  • Radio-femoral delay: Disparity in pulsation and BP in the arms and legs
  • Systolic or continuous murmurs are heard over the left and right sides of the chest laterally and posteriorly due to collateral blood flow.

Investigation:
  • Chest x-ray:
  • The arrows indicate rib notching and the yellow line shows the site of coarctation
  • Enlarged left subclavian artery produces a prominent shadow in the left superior mediastinum.
  • Notching of the inferior border of the ribs from pressure erosion by enlarged collateral vessels (Common in late childhood after 1st decade of life)
  • Descending aorta has an area of post-stenotic dilation.
  • ECG, echocardiography, colour Doppler, CT, and MRI.

Treatment:
  • Infusion of prostaglandin E1 to reopen the ductus and reestablish adequate lower-extremity blood flow.
  • Surgical repair

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presents with stable vitals and an ECG showing paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT). Which of the following is the appropriate treatment?
questions.explanation: Correct Option C - Adenosine 0.1 mg/kg

questions.text: What is the most common defect in a ventricular septal defect?

options.label: C
options.text: Non-development of the perimembranous part of the septum

questions.explanation:
Major

Minor

Systolic murmur grade III or more

Systolic murmur grade I or II

Diastolic murmur (Option A ruled out)

Abnormal second heart sound

Cyanosis

Abnormal ECG

Congestive cardiac failure (Option D ruled out)

Abnormal X-ray (Option C ruled out)
 

Abnormal Blood pressure

questions.text: A professor explains the pathophysiology of a “tet spell” and that it is due to a decrease in systemic vascular resistance that leads to more shunting of blood from right to left, causing an overload on the left side of the heart and decreasing the amount of blood reaching the lungs. Which of the following options determines the severity of the cyanotic spells?

options.label: A
options.text: Size of the ventricular septal defect (VSD)

questions.explanation: Correct Option D - Degree of pulmonary

questions.text: What is the most common congenital defect observed in individuals with Down syndrome?
questions.explanation: Correct Option C - Atrioventricular

questions.text: What is the primary factor for the closure of the ductus arteriosus after birth?

options.label: A

questions.text: Please match the appropriate answers related to cardiac abnormalities and their corresponding syndromes. 1) Noonan syndrome (A) PDA 2) Downs syndrome (B) Bicuspid aortic valve 3) Turner syndrome (C) Endocardial cushion defects 4) Congenital Rubella Syndrome (D) Pulmonary stenosis
questions.explanation:
Correct option B- 1-(D), 2-(C), 3-(B), 4-(A):

Congenital syndromes

Cardiac abnormalities

Noonan syndrome

Pulmonary stenosis

Down syndrome

Endocardial cushion defects

Turner syndrome

Bicuspid aortic valve

Congenital rubella syndrome

PDA

Congenital syndromes

Cardiac abnormalities

  

Noonan syndrome

Pulmonary stenosis

Pulmonary stenosis is a narrowing of the pulmonary valve, leading to obstruction of blood flow from the right ventricle to the pulmonary artery

Down syndrome

Endocardial cushion defects

Endocardial cushion defects involve abnormalities in the formation of the septum and valves of the heart, leading to a common atrioventricular canal defect

Turner syndrome

Bicuspid aortic valve

A bicuspid aortic valve is a congenital heart defect where the aortic valve has two leaflets instead of the normal three.

Congenital rubella syndrome

PDA

PDA is a condition where a blood vessel called the ductus arteriosus, which connects the pulmonary artery to the aorta during fetal development, remains open after birth

questions.text: Continuous murmur is heard in:
questions.explanation: Correct option A - Patent ductus arteriosu
